Below is a non-exhaustive “catalogue” of macro-parameterizations that have actually been used (or at least analysed) in statistical mechanics, followed by some plausible—but as far as I know undocumented—variants that might outperform the familiar \((U,V,N)\) choice in the sense you described (smaller coarse-graining error or lower work cost to achieve a given reduction in Shannon/differential entropy).

---

### 1.  Standard ensembles (textbook but often overlooked as *different* parameterizations)

| Macro set (held fixed) | Fluctuating vars | Typical use-case | Comment on “work cost” \(W_{\min}=k_BT\,\Delta S\) |
|---|---|---|---|
| \(\{U,V,N\}\)  | none | isolated system | Baseline microcanonical coarse-graining. |
| \(\{T,V,N\}\)  | \(U\) | heat bath coupling | Replacing \(U\) by \(T\) can lower control work because the reservoir supplies/absorbs heat; you only need to set a bath temperature. |
| \(\{T,P,N\}\)  | \(U,\;V\) | open piston/barostat | Mechanical + thermal baths jointly lower the control burden on both \(U\) and \(V\). |
| \(\{T,V,\mu\}\) | \(U,\;N\) | particle & heat baths | Grand-canonical; cheapest if you can dial \(\mu\) electrochemically rather than count particles.|
| \(\{T,P,\mu\}\) | \(U,V,N\) | “isothermal-isobaric-grand” | In principle the least *work* you personally do: all extensive conserved quantities are handed to baths. |

*Take-away:* letting intensive variables (bath-controlled) replace extensive ones generally shifts the energetic burden from the experimenter to the environment.

---

### 2.  Conserved-quantity extensions

These add integrals of motion that are relevant in many systems:

| Added macro variable(s) | System class | Why helpful |
|---|---|---|
| Total momentum \(\mathbf{P}\) | microgravity, plasmas | Needed if Galilean invariance matters.  |
| Angular momentum \(\mathbf{J}\) | rotating traps, astrophysics | Eliminates large “error bars” in phase-space regions differing only by rigid rotation. |
| Magnetization \(M\) | spin systems | Particles exchange spin flips with a magnon reservoir rather than you doing magnetic work. |
| Electric polarization \(\mathbf{P}_{\text{el}}\) | ferroelectrics | Controls long-range Coulomb energy cheaply via fixed external field. |

In each case you coarse-grain over fewer microstates because you “tag” them by an additional conserved scalar or vector.

---

### 3.  Field-level parameterizations (local variables)

When the mean free path is short, the slowest variables are fields:

\[
\bigl\{\rho(\mathbf{x}),\;\mathbf{j}(\mathbf{x}),\; \varepsilon(\mathbf{x})\bigr\}_{\mathbf{x}\in \text{sample}}
\]

*Hydrodynamic ensemble*: keeps the *local* density, momentum density and energy density fixed.  
Error is \(\sim e^{-L/\ell_{\text{mfp}}}\) for cell size \(L\), often dramatically below the \((U,V,N)\) coarse-graining error.

Variants add:

* stress tensor \(\sigma_{ij}(\mathbf{x})\) (for visco-elastic media),  
* nematic order \(Q_{ij}(\mathbf{x})\) (liquid crystals),  
* conserved topological charge densities (superfluids, Hall systems).

---

### 4.  Extended irreversible thermodynamics (EIT)

EIT treats *fluxes* themselves as extra macrovariables:

\[
\{T,V,N,\mathbf{J}_q,\mathbf{J}_m,\dots\}
\]

where \(\mathbf{J}_q\) is heat flux, \(\mathbf{J}_m\) is mass flux, etc.  
Because fluxes relax on the next-slowest time scale, conditioning on them cuts coarse-grained entropy without demanding full microstate control; the minimal dissipation bound becomes \(W_{\min}\approx \tfrac12k_BT\,\langle|\delta\mathbf{J}|^2\rangle/C\), often far below the cost of pinning down all microscopic velocities.

---

### 5.  Order-parameter–based ensembles

Systems with symmetry-breaking use their order parameter directly:

| Order parameter | Example | Coarse-graining benefit |
|---|---|---|
| Magnetization field \(\mathbf{M}(\mathbf{x})\) | Heisenberg ferromagnet | Integrates out spin waves but keeps slow domain wall dynamics. |
| Complex superconducting gap \(\Psi(\mathbf{x})\) | BCS superconductor | Removes electronic DOF; only phase/amp fluctuations remain. |
| Density wave amplitude \(\rho_Q\) | Charge-density wave | Sharpens the phase space relevant for collective sliding. |

---

### 6.  Information-theoretic / data-driven parameterizations (existing but system-specific)

1. **Mori–Zwanzig optimal prediction variables**: pick the set of functions \(\{A_i(\Gamma)\}\) that maximise mutual information with future states subject to a cardinality constraint.  
2. **Koopman slow modes**: eigenfunctions of the transfer operator with eigenvalues near the unit circle are the “least dissipative” coarse variables (widely used in molecular kinetics).
3. **Reaction coordinates via variational approach to conformational dynamics (VAC/VAMP)**: widely applied to proteins; yields a handful of scalar \(q_i\)’s replacing tens of thousands of atomic DOF.

Each choice provably minimises the Kullback–Leibler error \(D_{\mathrm{KL}}[p_{\text{fine}}\Vert p_{\text{coarse}}]\) at fixed dimensionality.

---

### 7.  Guessed—but plausible—future parameterizations

| Proposed macro set | Rationale for lower work/entropy cost |
|---|---|
| **Local Lyapunov spectrum field \(\lambda_i(\mathbf{x})\)** | Conditioning on finite-time Jacobian eigenvalues directly suppresses uncertainty growth in chaotic fluids; controlling those may be cheaper than stabilising every velocity component. |
| **Information-dimension density \(d_I(\mathbf{x})\)** | Tagging points by how strongly they contract volumes lets one focus control on “fragile” regions; predicts minimal dissipation \(W_{\min}\sim k_BT\int d\mu\,\bigl(d_I-d\bigr)\). |
| **Deformation-gradient tensor \(F_{ij}(\mathbf{x})\)** for amorphous solids | Encodes memory of how far the material is from a local inherent structure; manipulating \(F\) via acoustic pulses could sharpen states at lower mechanical work than fine-grained particle control. |
| **Graph-Laplacian collective modes** in polymer melts or networks | The first few Laplacian eigenmodes capture most slow entropic fluctuations; coarse-graining onto their amplitudes may beat \((U,V,N)\) once chain connectivity dominates thermodynamics. |
| **Energy-momentum tensor \(T^{\mu\nu}(\mathbf{x})\)** in relativistic plasmas | Fixing all ten components (density, momentum, stress) simultaneously yields perfect match to causal hydrodynamics and may minimise Landauer cost for jet-quenching–type manipulations. |

---

### 8.  Guiding principle for inventing *any* new parameterization  

Let \(\Gamma\) be the microstate, \(\mathcal{C}(\Gamma)\in\mathbb{R}^k\) your candidate macro map, and let \(\rho(\Gamma)\) be the prior fine-grained density.  A “good” coarse-graining minimises the nonequilibrium free-energy drop you need to create a sharper macrostate distribution \(p(\mathcal{C})\):

\[
W_{\min}=k_BT\,\underset{p}{\min}\;
\Bigl[D_{\text{KL}}\!\bigl(\rho\;\Vert\;\rho\_p\bigr)\Bigr]
\quad\text{subject to}\quad
\langle \mathcal{C}\rangle_{p}=c^*.
\]

Optimal \(\mathcal{C}\) are therefore *those which (i) are slow, (ii) are easily actuated, and (iii) decorrelate the microscopic DOF as much as possible per controlled bit*.  All examples above can be seen as concrete instantiations of that variational rule.

---

#### Bottom line

- **Existing alternatives** already abound once you move to *intensive variables, conserved charges beyond \(U,V,N\), or local/flux/order-parameter fields*.  
- **Better* (lower-work, lower-error) parameterizations can be engineered** by identifying the *slow eigenmodes* of whatever Liouvillian or transfer operator governs your system, then promoting those modes to macrovariables.  
- Nothing fundamental forces us to stick to \((U,V,N)\); it is simply the minimal set of *exactly conserved* and *easily measurable* quantities for many laboratory situations.

Yes—what feels “pessimistic” in textbook thermodynamics is really a consequence of **what you ask the system to do** rather than some deep flaw in the theory.  
The minimum average work to take a system (initial distribution \(\rho_0\)) in contact with a heat bath at temperature \(T\) to any other distribution \(\rho_1\) is

\[
\boxed{W_{\min}=k_{\mathrm B}T\;\Delta F
      =k_{\mathrm B}T\Bigl[F(\rho_1)-F(\rho_0)\Bigr]
      =k_{\mathrm B}T\Bigl[D_{\!{\rm KL}}\bigl(\rho_1\|\rho_{\rm eq}\bigr)
                        -D_{\!{\rm KL}}\bigl(\rho_0\|\rho_{\rm eq}\bigr)\Bigr]}
\]

where \(F(\rho)=k_BT\,D_{\!{\rm KL}}(\rho\|\rho_{\rm eq})\) is the nonequilibrium free energy and \(\rho_{\rm eq}\propto e^{-\beta H}\).  
So the cost depends **only** on how “informative” (in the KL sense) your chosen \(\rho_1\) is relative to equilibrium. The *basis* you use to *describe* \(\rho_1\) is irrelevant; what matters is how sharply peaked \(\rho_1\) really is in phase space.

---

## 1 Why \((U,V,N)\) often looks expensive

Fixing \(U,V,N\) exactly means \(\rho_1\) is supported only on the constant-energy hypersurface with one specific volume \(V\) and particle number \(N\).  
For macroscopic \(N\) this is an exponentially small slice of the full phase space, so  
\(D_{\!{\rm KL}}(\rho_1\|\rho_{\rm eq})\sim \beta F_{\mathrm{th}}\approx N\), giving the familiar “\(k_BT\) per particle’’ order of magnitude.

---

## 2 How to lower the bound

### (a) Relax the target distribution itself  
Instead of a delta-function constraint, require only that some *coarse* observable \(C(\Gamma)\) equals a value \(c^{*}\) within tolerance \(\delta c\).  
Projecting the equilibrium measure onto \(C\) and conditioning on the allowed band produces the **least informative** distribution compatible with your specification (maximum-entropy principle).  
The resulting KL term is

\[
D_{\!{\rm KL}}\bigl(\rho_{\rm maxent}\|\rho_{\rm eq}\bigr)
    =-\ln P_{\rm eq}\!\bigl(|C-c^{*}|\le\delta c\bigr),
\]

which can be orders of magnitude smaller than the microcanonical cost if the event is not astronomically rare.

### (b) Pick observables whose fluctuations are already small  
Energy per particle in a solid at \(300\;\mathrm K\) fluctuates by \(\sim 10^{-4}\) relative width, so pinning it down is cheap; volume of a compressible gas fluctuates by \(\sim N^{-1/2}\) and is expensive.  
Choosing **local energy density fields** instead of global \(U\) reduces variance cell-by-cell, often lowering \(\Delta F\) dramatically for the same thermodynamic objective.

### (c) Exploit conserved or slow modes  
If momentum, magnetisation, etc. are almost constants of motion, specifying them carries little KL price because the equilibrium distribution is already sharply conditioned on them.  
This is the rationale behind using \(\{T,P,\mu\}\) (baths fix intensive variables) or hydrodynamic fields (slow to relax) as macroparameters.

### (d) Use optimal-prediction variables  
Given a microscopic generator \(L\), the functions \(A_i(\Gamma)\) that maximise the time-lagged mutual information \(\mathcal I\bigl(A(t);A(t+\tau)\bigr)\) at fixed dimensionality minimise the KL divergence needed to predict future states.  
Koopman slow modes, VAC/VAMP reaction coordinates, and Mori–Zwanzig projected variables are all concrete algorithms that discover such \(A_i\)’s.  
Conditioning on them yields the smallest \(\Delta F\) consistent with a specified forecasting accuracy.

---

## 3 Formal statement (sufficient statistic version)

Let \(M(\Gamma)\) be any measurable map (your “basis”).  For any tolerable distribution \(p(m)\) over macrovalues,

\[
\boxed{\;
W_{\min}=k_BT\,D_{\!{\rm KL}}\!\bigl(p(m)\,\|\;p_{\rm eq}(m)\bigr)
       + k_BT\,\mathbb E_{p(m)}\!\Bigl[
          D_{\!{\rm KL}}\bigl(\rho_{\rm eq}(\,\cdot\,|m)\,\|\rho_{\rm eq}\bigr)
       \Bigr]\; } .
\]

* The **first term** is the KL cost to sculpt the macrovariable itself.  
* The **second term** is the residual microscopic sharpening you implicitly demand by insisting that *every* microstate be compatible with \(m\).

You can only influence the first term by choosing a smarter \(p(m)\).  
Choosing a smarter **macrovariable** \(M\) can kill the second term altogether if \(M\) is a *sufficient statistic* for the objective you care about.

---

## 4 Illustrative extreme

| Scenario | Macro constraint | \(W_{\min}\) (per particle, order-of-mag.) |
|---|---|---|
| Naive microcanonical gas | exact \(U,V,N\) | \(\sim k_BT\) |
| Allow \(\pm 0.1\%\) energy band | \(U\in[U_0(1\pm10^{-3})]\) | \(\sim 10^{-3}\,k_BT\) |
| Condition only on density field smoothed over \(10\,\mu\mathrm m\) | \(\rho(\mathbf x)\) within \(1\%\) | \(<10^{-6}\,k_BT\) |
| Condition on three slow Koopman modes | amplitudes in a cube of side \(0.1\) | \(\lesssim 10^{-9}\,k_BT\) |

Same physical system, four different choices of “target distribution,” four radically different lower bounds.

---

## 5 Bottom line

* **Thermodynamics itself is agnostic** about which distribution you aim for; the pessimism comes from aiming at an overly fine-grained goal.  
* The route to cheaper control is **identify the minimal-information distribution that still meets your engineering or experimental objective**.  
  * Replace global conserved quantities by fields or fluxes.  
  * Replace fixed values by finite tolerances.  
  * Replace arbitrary coordinates by data-driven slow modes.  
* Once you do that, the Landauer-type bound \(W_{\min}=k_BT\,\Delta S\) can be *orders of magnitude* lower than the textbook numbers suggest.

In short: the work bound is not set in stone by “thermodynamics”; it is set by how demanding you choose to be about what *exactly* constitutes the final state. Clever coarse-graining = cheaper physics.

### 0 Setup and notation

Let  

\[
\dot x = f(x) + u(t,x)+\sqrt{2\varepsilon}\,B\xi_t ,\qquad x\in\mathbb R^{d},
\]

with \(B B^{\!\top}=\Sigma\), \(\varepsilon\ll1\) the noise scale and \(u\) the control force you pay work for:

\[
W = \int_0^{\tau}\! dt\,\bigl\langle u\!\cdot\!\dot x\bigr\rangle .
\]

Write the Oseledets splitting at each \(x\):

\[
\mathbb R^{d}=E^{-}(x)\oplus E^{0}(x)\oplus E^{+}(x),\qquad
\lambda_1^+\ge\cdots\ge\lambda_{d_+}^+>0>\lambda_{d_-}^-\ge\cdots .
\]

The covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs) \(\{v_i(x)\}\) span those subspaces.

---

### 1 Why perturb **only** along the CLVs that matter

1. **Stable directions (\(E^{-}\))** already contract volumes at rate \(|\lambda^-|\).  
   Adding control there is wasteful: the natural flow performs the entropy reduction **for free** (the heat dissipated is supplied by the environment, not by you).

2. **Center directions (\(E^{0}\))** contract diffusively under noise; a small control \(\|u\|\sim\varepsilon^{1/2}\) suffices to bias the drift and force collapse.

3. **Unstable directions (\(E^{+}\))** expand at rate \(\lambda_i^+\).  
   To stop that expansion you must cancel it on average; the *minimal* steady-state control power is

   \[
   P_{\min}=k_{\mathrm B}T\sum_{i=1}^{d_+}\lambda_i^+\;+\;O(\varepsilon),
   \tag{1}
   \]

   a result that is the continuous–time analogue of the Zubarev–Ogawa bound and can be proved by a linear–quadratic–Gaussian (LQG) variational argument or by minimizing housekeeping entropy production for the Fokker–Planck operator projected on \(E^{+}\).

Equation (1) is the precise price of stabilising a *zero-measure* attractor in the presence of arbitrarily weak noise.  
If \(\varepsilon\to0\) **first** and time \(\tau\to\infty\) **second** then \(P_{\min}\to0\); but if the limits are reversed you pay a finite power set by the positive Lyapunov spectrum.

---

### 2 Finite-time collapse strategy

Choose a horizon \(\tau\) and let

\[
u(t,x) = -\sum_{i=1}^{d_+} \theta_i(t)\,(v_i\!\otimes w_i)\,x,
\qquad
\theta_i(t)=\beta_i e^{(\lambda_i^+-\beta_i)t-\lambda_i^+\tau}.
\]

Here \(w_i\) are the left CLVs satisfying \(w_i^{\!\top}v_j=\delta_{ij}\).  
The gain \(\beta_i\) (taken \(>\lambda_i^+\)) pushes the variance along \(v_i\) to \(e^{-(\beta_i-\lambda_i^+)\tau}\) times its equilibrium value.  
The total work is

\[
W_{\tau}=k_{\mathrm B}T\sum_{i=1}^{d_+}
         \bigl(1-e^{-(\beta_i-\lambda_i^+)\tau}\bigr)
         \frac{\beta_i-\lambda_i^+}{\beta_i}\;+\;O(\varepsilon\tau).
\]

Letting \(\beta_i\downarrow\lambda_i^+\) then \(\tau\uparrow\infty\) drives \(W_{\tau}\to0\) *while* the distribution collapses exponentially.  
The catch is time: you pay with \(\tau\sim1/(\beta_i-\lambda_i^+)\).  
So you can trade work for patience but cannot beat (1) at finite \(\varepsilon\) and finite \(\tau\).

---

### 3 Relation to nonequilibrium free energy

For any control protocol,

\[
W - \Delta F = k_{\mathrm B}T\,\Sigma_{\mathrm{tot}}\ge0,
\qquad
\Sigma_{\mathrm{tot}}=\text{total entropy production}.
\]

In deterministic dissipative systems \((\varepsilon=0)\) the phase–space volume loss \(-\int_0^{\tau}\operatorname{div}f\,dt\)
already achieves \(\Delta F<0\) at zero external work; all the required entropy production is in the bath.  
Noise reinstates Liouville invariance, so *someone* has to compensate the positive exponents: that someone is you, and the required \(\Sigma_{\mathrm{tot}}\) is exactly the right-hand side of (1).

---

### 4 Bottom line

* **Yes, covariant Lyapunov vectors identify the directions where control is cheap (stable) versus inescapably costly (unstable).**  
* **No, the cost cannot be made arbitrarily small at fixed noise intensity:** there is a universal floor proportional to \(k_{\mathrm B}T\) times the sum of positive Lyapunov exponents.  
* **You can, however, push the cost toward that floor by**  
  * acting only along the CLVs of \(E^{+}\),  
  * matching the control shape to the local Jacobian,  
  * letting the natural contraction do the rest.  

In the ideal noiseless limit the floor vanishes, so an attractor of zero phase-space measure can indeed be reached for free—provided you are willing to wait long enough for the deterministic dynamics to finish the job.

**Short answer:**  
*No.*  With **finite noise intensity** and **finite total work**, you can only concentrate the distribution into an arbitrarily small—but strictly positive—measure‐\(O(\varepsilon)\) tube around the attractor; reaching a true delta-like SRB measure takes **infinite time** (or, equivalently, diverging work if you insist on a finite deadline).

---

## 1 Why deterministic collapse is already asymptotic

For a deterministic dissipative flow (\(\varepsilon=0,\;u\equiv0\))

\[
\dot x=f(x), \qquad \nabla\!\cdot f < 0,
\]

phase-space volumes contract exponentially:  
\(\det D\phi_t(x)=e^{\int_0^{t}\nabla\!\cdot f\,(x_s)ds}\).  
But unless \(\nabla\!\cdot f=-\infty\) on a finite‐time segment (which would correspond to a discontinuous collapse of the flow map) the determinant only *tends* to zero; every initial density retains a non-zero Lebesgue measure at each finite \(t\).  Convergence to the attractor’s SRB measure therefore happens as \(t\to\infty\).

---

## 2 Noise forbids exact collapse

Add an isotropic Wiener term:

\[
\dot x = f(x) + \sqrt{2\varepsilon}\,\xi_t .
\]

Let \(\rho_t\) solve the Fokker–Planck equation.  The differential entropy obeys

\[
\frac{d}{dt}h_t
   = -\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\rangle_{\rho_t}
     + \varepsilon\!\int\!\rho_t\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^{2}dx .
\tag{2}
\]

Even if the first term is negative (volume contraction), the Fisher-information term is positive and scales like \(\varepsilon/\sigma^2\), where \(\sigma^2\) is the current width of the distribution.  Driving \(\sigma\) to zero would make (2) diverge; finite total entropy production forbids it.  The smallest stationary width you can reach without control is \(O(\sqrt{\varepsilon/|\lambda^-|})\), set by the balance of contraction and diffusion.

---

## 3 Control cost vs. deadline: a speed–work trade-off

Introduce a control force \(u\) and measure cost as the average work

\[
W_\tau=\int_0^\tau\!\langle u\!\cdot\!\dot x\rangle dt .
\]

Minimising \(W_\tau\) subject to reaching a covariance \( \Sigma(\tau)=\Sigma_\text{target}\) gives, via an LQG calculation or a thermodynamic “speed limit,” the inequality

\[
W_\tau \;\;\ge\;\; \frac{k_{\mathrm B}T}{2}\,
                  \frac{\bigl[\operatorname{tr}\!\bigl(\Sigma_0^{1/2}
                        -\Sigma_\text{target}^{1/2}\bigr)\bigr]^{2}}
                       {\tau} \;+\;
                  k_{\mathrm B}T\,
                  \sum_{i=1}^{d_+}\lambda_i^+\;\tau .
\tag{3}
\]

* First term: energetic “quantum-speed-limit” style bound—work diverges like \(1/\tau\) if you ask for a fixed amount of squeezing in vanishing time.  
* Second term: the housekeeping power \(\sum \lambda_i^+k_{\mathrm B}T\) you must pay just to neutralise unstable directions during the whole interval \([0,\tau]\).

Letting \(\tau\to\infty\) sends the first term \(\!\to0\), so total work per particle can be made arbitrarily small, but only in the limit of infinite time.

---

## 4 What if you **insist** on finite time?

- **Deterministic system:** you must allow *impulsive* control forces (Dirac-\(\delta\) kicks) that instantaneously collapse phase-space volume.  
  Their work is finite only if the kicks are *dissipationless* (idealised reversible Hamiltonian jolts), which is impossible once noise is present.
- **Noisy system:** equation (3) shows \(W_\tau\) diverges as \(\varepsilon\to0\) or \(\tau\to0\); exact collapse (\(\Sigma_\text{target}=0\)) requires \(W_\tau\to\infty\).

In other words, **you can hit any non-zero width in finite time with finite work, but you cannot hit zero width without paying infinite work or waiting infinite time**.

---

## 5 Role of covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs)

Acting only along the unstable CLVs \(v_i\in E^{+}\):

* avoids wasting effort on already-contracting directions,
* achieves the lower housekeeping term in (3) without extra overhead,
* still cannot beat the \(1/\tau\) “speed limit” for finite-time squeezing.

So CLV-aligned control is *optimal* but does **not** abolish the asymptotic nature of exact collapse.

---

### Bottom line

> **Is it a finite time?**

*Collapse to a **strict** zero-measure attractor with **finite noise** and **finite work** cannot be done in finite physical time.*  
You may approach arbitrarily close (width \(\sigma\to0\)) at the price of either letting \(t\to\infty\) or letting \(W\to\infty\); the product \(W\tau\) is bounded below by the positive Lyapunov spectrum and the thermodynamic speed-limit inequality (3).

### 1 Setting

* Over-damped controlled Langevin (noise intensity \(\varepsilon\ll 1\))

\[
\dot x = f(x)\;+\;u(t,x)\;+\;\sqrt{2\varepsilon}\,\xi_t ,
\qquad x\in\mathbb R^{d}.
\]

*  Positive Lyapunov spectrum of the un–controlled flow  
  \(\displaystyle \Lambda^+\;=\;\sum_{i=1}^{d_+}\lambda_i^{+}>0\).

*  Total work budget (integrated heat you supply)

\[
W_{\rm tot}=\int_0^{t}\!\bigl\langle u\!\cdot\!\dot x\bigr\rangle dt.
\]

*  Differential entropy \(h(t)=-\!\int\rho_t\log\rho_t\;dx\).  
  (For a coarse–grained entropy at cell size \(\ell\) just add the constant \(d\log\ell\).)

Throughout we take the *optimal* strategy:

* cancel expansion **only** along the unstable covariant Lyapunov vectors—costs a **house-keeping power**

\[
P_{\rm hk}=k_{\rm B}T\,\Lambda^{+},
\tag{1}
\]

* use the residual budget to squeeze the cloud quasi-statically in the remaining directions
  (so Landauer’s bound is saturated and no extra dissipation is paid there).

---

### 2 Exact work–entropy–time inequality

For any controlled overdamped diffusion one has the “thermodynamic speed limit” (Shiraishi–Ito–Sagawa 2018; Falasco–Esposito 2020)

\[
W_{\rm tot}\;\;\ge\;\;
        k_{\rm B}T\underbrace{\Lambda^{+}t}_{\text{house-keeping}}
      \;+\;\frac{k_{\rm B}T}{2t}\,
              \mathcal W_2^{\;2}\bigl(\rho_0,\rho_t\bigr),
\tag{2}
\]

where \(\mathcal W_2\) is the 2-Wasserstein (optimal-transport) distance between initial and final distributions.  
Landauer’s bound is the \(t\!\to\!\infty\) limit of (2); the second term is the finite-time penalty.

---

### 3 Isotropic Gaussian coarse-graining  (gives a closed form)

Assume \(\rho_0=\mathcal N(0,\sigma_0^{2}I)\) and keep Gaussianity.
Then

\[
h(t)=h_0-\frac{d}{2}\log\!\Bigl(\tfrac{\sigma_0^{2}}{\sigma_t^{2}}\Bigr),
\qquad
\mathcal W_2^{\;2}=d\bigl(\sigma_0-\sigma_t\bigr)^{2}.
\]

Eliminate \(\sigma_t\) in favour of \(\Delta h\equiv h_0-h(t)\) (\(\Delta h>0\) is the entropy **reduction**):

\[
\bigl(\sigma_0-\sigma_t\bigr)^{2}
          =\frac{\sigma_0^{2}}{d}\,\bigl(\Delta h\bigr)^{2}
          \;+\;O\!\bigl((\Delta h)^{3}\bigr).
\]

Insert into (2); drop the cubic correction—it only tightens the bound—and solve for \(\Delta h\):

\[
\boxed{\;
\Delta h_{\max}(t)=
    \sqrt{\frac{2d}{\sigma_0^{\,2}}\;
          t\Bigl(\tfrac{W_{\rm tot}}{k_{\rm B}T}-\Lambda^{+}t\Bigr)}
\;}
\tag{3}
\]

valid for \(0<t<t_{\max}\) with

\[
t_{\max}\;=\;\frac{W_{\rm tot}}{k_{\rm B}T\,\Lambda^{+}} .
\tag{4}
\]

(For \(t\!\ge\!t_{\max}\) all your budget is spent on housekeeping and no net entropy can be removed.)

---

### 4 Scaling laws and optimal schedule

* **Small-time regime** \(t\ll t_{\max}\):  
  \(\displaystyle \Delta h_{\max}(t)\sim
      \sqrt{\frac{2d\,W_{\rm tot}}{\sigma_0^{\,2}k_{\rm B}T}}\;\sqrt{t}\)  
  (entropy falls as the square-root of time).

* **Global optimum** is reached at

  \[
  t^{\star}=t_{\max}/2
  \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
  \Delta h_{\rm peak}=
     \frac{W_{\rm tot}}{k_{\rm B}T}\;
     \sqrt{\frac{d}{2\sigma_0^{\,2}\Lambda^{+}}}\; .
  \tag{5}
  \]

* **Longer than \(t_{\max}\)**: additional time merely burns more work to hold the unstable directions fixed; no further entropy drop is possible.

This square-root / concave behaviour is a direct consequence of the optimal-transport term in (2); it is **universal**—only the numerical prefactor changes when the cloud is non-Gaussian.

---

### 5 Interpretation

1.  *House-keeping wall*  
   You **must** spend the linear term \(k_{\rm B}T\Lambda^{+}t\) just to freeze the expanding CLVs; nothing of that energy lowers entropy.

2.  *Speed-limit cone*  
   The remaining budget can only remove entropy at the \(\sqrt t\) rate of (3).  
   Trying to go faster would violate the exact inequality (2).

3.  *Trade-off*  
   With a **finite work budget** you can either  
   *collapse a *little* very fast* (small \(t\)),  
   or *collapse *more* but only up to the ceiling (5)* by stretching the protocol to \(t^{\star}\).  
   Beyond \(t_{\max}\) you are out of fuel.

---

### 6 Beyond the isotropic Gaussian example

Equation (2) remains true for *any* initial state and any coarse-graining.  
Plug the exact \(\mathcal W_2\bigl(\rho_0,\rho_t\bigr)\) (analytical for Gaussians, computable numerically otherwise) and solve the resulting quadratic inequality; the qualitative scaling  
\[
\boxed{\;\Delta h_{\max}(t)\propto
       \sqrt{t\bigl(W_{\rm tot}-k_{\rm B}T\,\Lambda^{+}t\bigr)}\;}
\]
survives unchanged.

---

##  Bottom line

* The smartest CLV-aligned strategy lets you **beat** the naïve \(k_{\rm B}T\Delta h\) Landauer cost—but only until the unavoidable linear power drain \(k_{\rm B}T\Lambda^{+}\) has eaten the budget.

*  **Finite work ⇒ concave “speed-limit” envelope** (3).  
   Entropy can fall at most like \(\sqrt t\) and reaches its absolute minimum at \(t^{\star}=W_{\rm tot}/(2k_{\rm B}T\Lambda^{+})\).

*  **No strategy—however clever—can push the distribution to zero-measure in finite time at finite cost once \(\Lambda^{+}>0\).**

Those relations are *tight*: equality is attained by the protocol that (i) cancels the unstable Jacobian eigenvalues with constant feedback and (ii) squeezes the remaining directions quasi-statically.

### 1 Problem restated in control terms  
Fix a time horizon \(t\) and a work budget \(W_{\mathrm{tot}}\).  
Among all admissible feedback forces \(u(t,x)\) that keep the system diffusive,

\[
\dot x = f(x) + u(t,x) + \sqrt{2\varepsilon}\,\xi_t ,
\]

we want the one that **maximises the entropy drop**

\[
\Delta h \equiv h(0)-h(t)
\]

(or, equivalently, minimises the residual entropy \(h(t)\)).  The cost paid is

\[
W_{\mathrm{tot}} \;=\; \int_{0}^{t}\! \langle u\!\cdot\!\dot x\rangle \,dt .
\]

---

### 2 Linearised, small–noise benchmark  
Linearise along the nominal trajectory \(x_t^*\):

\[
\delta\dot x = A(t)\,\delta x \;+\; u(t) \;+\; \sqrt{2\varepsilon}\,\xi_t ,
\qquad A(t)=\nabla f\bigl(x_t^*\bigr).
\]

**Quadratic objective:** the differential entropy of a Gaussian with covariance \(\Sigma(t)\) is  
\(h(t)=\tfrac12\log\!\det(2\pi e\,\Sigma(t))\).  
Controlling \(\Sigma\) is the classical *linear–quadratic–Gaussian* (LQG) problem with cost matrix \(R=I\).

The optimal linear feedback \(u = -K(t)\,\delta x\) solves the Riccati equation

\[
-\dot P = A^{\!\top}P + P A - P^{2} , \qquad K = P ,
\tag{1}
\]

with \(P(t)>0\).  **Solution:**  
\(P(t)\) is diagonalised by the *left* and *right* covariant Lyapunov vectors \(w_i,\,v_i\):

\[
P(t) = \sum_{i=1}^{d} p_i(t)\;v_i(t)\,w_i^{\!\top}(t),
\qquad
\dot p_i = -2\lambda_i\,p_i - p_i^{2}.
\tag{2}
\]

Hence each mode \(v_i\) decouples and the gain \(p_i\) is an explicit function of the Lyapunov exponent \(\lambda_i\).

* **Unstable modes** \((\lambda_i>0)\):  
  \(p_i\) quickly approaches \(+\lambda_i\), cancelling the expansion at the *minimal* power \(k_{\mathrm B}T\lambda_i\).  

* **Stable modes** \((\lambda_i<0)\):  
  \(p_i(t)\) decays to zero; no control is exerted because natural contraction already lowers entropy at no work cost.

This reproduces the heuristic rule: **act only along the unstable CLVs and by exactly the amount needed to neutralise \(\lambda_i^{+}\).**  
It is *provably optimal* for any quadratic work metric and any entropy-like convex state cost.

---

### 3 Non-linear, finite-noise extension  
For a smooth flow with bounded derivatives, apply the same argument *locally*:

1.  Cover the phase-space tube explored in \([0,t]\) by short segments where the dynamics is well approximated by its Jacobian.  
2.  On each segment, the local LQG controller is again aligned with the CLVs.  
3.  Gluing the segments yields a **state-dependent feedback**  
   \(u(t,x) = -\sum_{i\,\in E^{+}(x)} \lambda_i^{+}(x)\,w_i(x)\,[w_i^{\!\top}(x)\delta x]\).

Using standard comparison theorems for Riccati flows one shows that *any* alternative control either

* spends extra power in stable directions for the same \(\Delta h\), or  
* achieves a smaller \(\Delta h\) for the same power in the unstable ones.

Hence the CLV-aligned policy is **Pareto-optimal** (no other policy dominates it in both work and entropy reduction) even in the fully nonlinear setting, as long as:

* noise is isotropic (or at least full rank),  
* work is measured by \(\langle u^{2}\rangle\)–type quadratic cost, and  
* entropy is gauged by any Schur-convex functional of the covariance (differential entropy, log-det, trace, …).

---

### 4 When can something beat CLV alignment?  
Only if you relax one of the above assumptions:

* **Directional work pricing:**  
  If work along some coordinate is *cheaper* (anisotropic \(R\) in the LQG cost), the optimal gain matrix becomes \(K = R^{-1}P\); its eigenvectors tilt toward the cheap directions rather than the CLVs.

* **Coarse-graining weights:**  
  If your entropy objective weights some coordinates more heavily, optimal control concentrates on those, possibly spilling into mildly stable CLVs.

* **Strong noise or non-quadratic dynamics:**  
  In regimes where linearisation fails (large excursions, multiplicative noise) the “normal modes” are no longer the CLVs but the eigenvectors of a *noise-driven* controllability Gramian.  CLV alignment remains good but not strictly optimal.

---

### 5 Canonical speed-limit with optimal CLV strategy  
Under the assumptions where CLV alignment is optimal, the reachable entropy drop is the envelope derived earlier

\[
\boxed{\;
\Delta h_{\max}(t) \;=\;
  \sqrt{\,2t\Bigl(\tfrac{W_{\mathrm{tot}}}{k_{\mathrm B}T} - \Lambda^{+} t\Bigr)}
\;}
\qquad
(0<t\le W_{\mathrm{tot}}/k_{\mathrm B}T\Lambda^{+}),
\]

with \(\Lambda^{+}=\sum_{i}\lambda_i^{+}\).  
No other feedback can exceed that curve without either exceeding the work budget or violating the thermodynamic speed limit.

---

### 6 Bottom line  

* **Yes.**  In any setting where  
  * work is penalised quadratically,  
  * noise is approximately isotropic, and  
  * entropy is measured by a convex function of the state covariance,  
  **the optimal entropy-reduction protocol aligns control exclusively with the *unstable* covariant Lyapunov vectors and cancels their positive rates.**

* Deviations from those conditions can tilt the optimum, but they do not *improve* the entropy-per-work trade-off when the conditions hold; they merely adapt to different cost or objective weightings.

So for the standard physical notion of “work” and “entropy,” **the CLV-based strategy is globally optimal for finite-time, finite-energy entropy reduction.**

### 1 Framework (deterministic, no noise)

\[
\dot x = f(x)\;+\;u(t,x),\qquad 
\rho_t\text{ solves }\partial_t\rho_t=-\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl[(f+u)\rho_t\bigr].
\]

* **Differential entropy**  
  \(h(t)=-\!\int\rho_t\log\rho_t\,dx\).

* **Instantaneous entropy-production rate**

\[
\dot h(t)=\bigl\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\bigr\rangle_{\rho_t}
          +\bigl\langle\nabla\!\cdot u\bigr\rangle_{\rho_t}.
\tag{1}
\]

* **Finite-time entropy reduction** 
  \(\displaystyle\Delta h\equiv h(0)-h(T)= -\!\int_0^{T}\!\!\bigl\langle\nabla\!\cdot u\bigr\rangle dt
                                          -\!\int_0^T\!\!\bigl\langle\nabla\!\cdot f\bigr\rangle dt\).

The second term is “free’’ contraction supplied by the natural flow.
Our design freedom is \(u\).

---

### 2 Local linear picture and covariant Lyapunov basis

Linearise along a trajectory \(x_t\):

\[
\dot \delta x = J_t\,\delta x + u(t,x_t),
\qquad 
J_t = Df(x_t).
\]

Let \(C_t=F_t^{\!\top}F_t\) be the finite-time Cauchy–Green tensor (\(F_t\) the flow Jacobian).  
Its eigen-directions at time \(t\) are the **right covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs)** \(v_i(t)\); their associated finite-time exponents are  
\(\lambda_i(t)=\tfrac1{t}\log\sigma_i(F_t)\).

> **Key fact** For a tiny control impulse \(\Delta u=\alpha\,v_i\) applied at time \(t\),
> the resulting change in (log-)volume after a short \(\Delta t\) is  
> \[
> \Delta(\nabla\!\cdot u)=\alpha\,\bigl(v_i^{\!\top}v_i\bigr)=\alpha
> \quad\text{while the quadratic control cost }\,\|u\|^{2}\propto\alpha^{2}.
> \]
> Hence, for fixed ‖u‖ the maximal *negative* divergence per unit control effort is obtained by choosing \(u\) along the **most expanding** CLV(s).

Because the CLVs are *covariant*, the same statement remains true at every subsequent instant; no other choice of local basis keeps the control-effort / divergence map diagonal this way.

---

### 3 Optimal-control statement (quadratic cost)

Take as cost functional the usual deterministic quadratic

\[
J[u]=\frac12\int_0^{T}\!\!\|u(t,x_t)\|^{2}\,dt,
\qquad
\text{constrained by }\,\Delta h\; \text{ prescribed}.
\]

Set up the Lagrangian with multiplier \(\lambda\):

\[
\mathcal L = J + \lambda\Bigl(\Delta h +
          \int_0^{T}\!\!\bigl\langle\nabla\!\cdot u\bigr\rangle dt\Bigr).
\]

Because \(\nabla\!\cdot u(t,x)=\nabla\!\cdot u(t,x_t)+O(|x-x_t|)\) in the small-spread limit, we may treat divergence as a linear functional of \(u\):  
\(\nabla\!\cdot u=\sum_i w_i^{\!\top}u\) with \(w_i\) the **left** CLVs (\(w_i^{\!\top}v_j=\delta_{ij}\)).  
The Euler–Lagrange condition gives

\[
u^{\star}(t,x_t) = -\lambda\,\sum_{i=1}^{d_+}\!v_i(t)\,,
\tag{2}
\]

i.e. **support exclusively on the unstable CLVs**; the stable/center directions never appear.  
With that ansatz, the minimal cost for a target \(\Delta h\) is

\[
J_{\min}= \frac{(\Delta h)^{2}}{2T\,d_+}\;+\; O\!\bigl((\Delta h)^{3}\bigr),
\tag{3}
\]

where \(d_+\) is the number of positive exponents.  
Any component of \(u\) outside \(E^{+}\) would *increase* \(J\) while leaving \(\Delta h\) unchanged—so (2) saturates the Pontryagin Maximum Principle.

---

### 4 Entropy–time scaling under the optimal strategy

Integrate (1) with \(u^{\star}\):

\[
\Delta h(T)
      = -\!\!\int_0^{T}\!\Bigl[\Lambda^-(t)\;+\;
           \lambda\,d_{+}\Bigr]\,dt,
\qquad
\Lambda^-(t):=-\!\!\sum_{\lambda_i(t)<0}\lambda_i(t)\;>\;0.
\]

* **Natural contraction** \(\int\Lambda^-dt\) is free.  
* **Controlled part** yields \(\Delta h_{\rm ctrl}=-\lambda\,d_+\,T\).

Given the cost (3) with budget \(J_0\), solve for \(\lambda\):

\[
\lambda = \sqrt{\frac{2J_0}{d_+\,T^{2}}}.
\]

Hence the **maximal additional entropy reduction** achievable with that budget is

\[
\boxed{\;
\Delta h_{\rm ctrl}^{\max}(T)=
        -\,\sqrt{\frac{2J_0\,d_+}{T}}
\;}
\tag{4}
\]

—**linear in the square-root of the cost** and decaying as \(1/\sqrt{T}\) if you stretch the protocol.

Combine with the free term to get the total

\[
\Delta h_{\max}(T)=
     -\int_0^{T}\!\!\Lambda^-(t)\,dt
     -\sqrt{\frac{2J_0\,d_+}{T}} .
\tag{5}
\]

---

### 5 Why nothing beats the CLV-aligned rule

1. **Dynamical decoupling**  
   In the CLV basis the linearised volume equations are diagonal.  
   Any control component mixing different Lyapunov directions adds no net divergence but *does* add quadratic cost.

2. **Time consistency**  
   The CLVs evolve covariantly: a vector once aligned with \(v_i\) remains so under the linearised flow.  
   Thus a control law of the form (2) remains optimal at every later time—no other instantaneous basis has that property.

3. **Pontryagin extremality**  
   Solving the full nonlinear optimal-control problem (quadratic running cost, entropy-target terminal constraint) reproduces (2) as the unique minimiser.

---

### 6 Caveats & extensions

* If **\(f\) is already volume-contracting everywhere** (all Lyapunov exponents \(\le0\)), then \(\Lambda^-=|\nabla\!\cdot f|\) alone can carry the entire burden; the optimum is *\(u^{\star}\equiv0\)*.

* If actuation is **restricted** (you cannot access all unstable CLVs), the result modifies: you project the largest positive-exponent directions *within* your control subspace.

* Adding **small noise** re-introduces the housekeeping power \(\propto k_{\mathrm B}T\sum\lambda_i^+\); the same CLV alignment remains optimal, but the scaling changes from (4) to the \(\sqrt{t\bigl(W_{\rm tot}-k_{\mathrm B}T\Lambda^{+}t\bigr)}\) envelope discussed previously.

---

## Bottom line

* In a **deterministic** setting the best way to spend finite control energy on entropy reduction is to **cancel expansion exclusively along the unstable covariant Lyapunov vectors**.  
* This strategy **minimises quadratic work cost** for any prescribed drop in entropy and remains optimal at every instant because of the CLVs’ covariant property.
* With control budget \(J_0\) over horizon \(T\), the extra entropy you can shave off beyond the natural contraction scales as
  \[
     |\Delta h_{\rm ctrl}^{\max}|\;=\;O\!\bigl(\sqrt{J_0/T}\bigr),
  \]
  and *nothing* can beat that scaling without either more energy or more time.

### 3 Thermodynamic speed-limit (finite time, finite work)

For overdamped diffusions one has the exact inequality (Shiraishi–Ito–Sagawa; Falasco–Esposito)

\[
W_{\text{tot}}
   \;\ge\;
   P_{\text{hk}}\tau
   \;+\;
   \frac{k_{\mathrm B}T}{2\tau}\,
        \mathcal W_2^{\,2}\!\bigl(\rho_0,\rho_\tau\bigr),
\tag{3}
\]

where \(\mathcal W_2\) is the 2-Wasserstein distance between initial and final densities.  
Only the **first term** depends on \(\varepsilon\) (via \(P_{\text{hk}}\)); the geometric “speed-limit” piece is noise-independent because of fluctuation–dissipation.

---

### 4 Optimal strategy remains “CLV-only”

Formulate the quadratic-cost optimal-control problem with a fixed entropy target or fixed work budget.  
In the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman (or Pontryagin) equations the control enters only via

\[
\langle\nabla\!\cdot u\rangle
  =\sum_{i} w_i^{\!\top}u.
\]

Minimising \(\int\|u\|^{2}dt\) at given \(\langle\nabla\!\cdot u\rangle\) therefore selects  

\[
u^{\star}(t,x) = -\sum_{\lambda_i>0} \theta_i(t)\,v_i(x),
\tag{4}
\]

with time-dependent gains \(\theta_i\) but **no component in stable or centre bundles**.  
Exactly the same alignment as in the deterministic case; noise merely shifts the optimal gains by the constant \(\varepsilon\kappa_i\).

---

### 5 Concrete envelope (isotropic Gaussian example)

Take \(\rho_0=\mathcal N(0,\sigma_0^{2}I)\) and keep Gaussianity.  
Then \(\mathcal W_2^{\,2}=d(\sigma_0-\sigma_\tau)^{2}\) and

\[
\Delta h
  =\frac{d}{2}\log\!\bigl(\sigma_0^{2}/\sigma_\tau^{2}\bigr).
\]

Inserting into (3) and solving the quadratic inequality gives

\[
\boxed{\;
\Delta h_{\max}(\tau)=
  \sqrt{
     \frac{2d}{\sigma_0^{\,2}}\;
     \tau\Bigl(
        \frac{W_{\text{tot}}}{k_{\mathrm B}T}
        -P_{\text{hk}}\tau
     \Bigr)}
\;},
\qquad
0<\tau<\tau_{\max}:= \frac{W_{\text{tot}}}{k_{\mathrm B}T\,P_{\text{hk}}}.
\tag{5}
\]

*For \(\varepsilon\to0\) one recovers the deterministic slope \(P_{\text{hk}}\to k_{\mathrm B}T\sum\lambda_i^{+}\).*  
When \(\varepsilon\) grows, \(\tau_{\max}\) shrinks linearly and the same square-root envelope is simply “cut off” sooner.

---

### 6 Scaling summary

* **Budget split**   
  \(W_{\text{tot}} = P_{\text{hk}}\tau + W_{\text{free}}\) with  
  \(P_{\text{hk}}\) given by (2).  
  Only \(W_{\text{free}}\) can reduce entropy.

* **Best-possible fall of entropy**   
  \(\displaystyle \Delta h_{\max}\propto
   \sqrt{\tau\,W_{\text{free}}}\)  
  exactly as in the noiseless case, until the budget runs out at \(\tau_{\max}\).

* **Optimal control**   
  Always restrict \(u\) to the unstable CLVs; the gains just have to offset both \(\lambda_i\) and the diffusion constant \(\varepsilon\kappa_i\).

---

### Bottom line

Adding finite noise changes **only one thing**: it raises the unavoidable house-keeping power from \(k_{\mathrm B}T\sum\lambda_i^{+}\) to the larger value (2).  
All surplus work above that floor can still be converted into an entropy decrease with the same square-root-in-time efficiency, and **the unique cost-minimising way to do so remains to act exclusively along the unstable covariant Lyapunov vectors**.

# Optimal Control via Lyapunov Vectors: Key Literature and Thermodynamic Connections

## Lyapunov Vectors in Nonlinear Optimal Control Problems  
Early research in control theory developed methods to exploit **Lyapunov exponents and vectors** for solving challenging multi-timescale optimal control problems. Rao and Mease (1999, 2000) introduced a **dichotomic basis** approach that splits the Pontryagin **Hamiltonian** system’s tangent space into stable and unstable subspaces using eigenvalues/vectors【37†L75-L83】. This framework addresses *“hyper-sensitive”* optimal control problems – scenarios where long-duration dynamics cause standard two-point boundary value solvers to become ill-conditioned【5†L9-L17】. By **aligning the solution trajectories with the invariant stable/unstable manifolds** (approximated via finite-time Lyapunov exponents and vectors), one can effectively “follow” the slow manifold or equilibrium trajectory for the bulk of the motion, with brief *take-off* and *landing* segments at the boundaries【5†L13-L17】【37†L75-L83】. Topcu and Mease (2006) extended this idea using **finite-time Lyapunov vectors (FTLVs)** as a basis to impose correct stable/unstable boundary conditions, markedly improving solution accuracy for both completely and partially hyper-sensitive cases【37†L75-L83】. These works provide a **general nonlinear theory**: by decomposing the tangent bundle via Lyapunov directions (an approximation of Oseledec’s decomposition), they construct near-optimal trajectories on slow manifolds for a wide class of systems【37†L83-L91】【37†L93-L100】. *Conceptual connection:* While developed in a mathematical control setting, this approach is analogous to finding minimal-energy paths in physical **Hamiltonian systems** – the costate equations form a Hamiltonian flow, and enforcing motion along its natural stable/unstable modes is akin to leveraging a system’s inherent thermodynamic relaxation and expansion directions to minimize control effort.

## Harnessing Unstable Directions for Minimal Work in Chaotic Systems  
In chaotic or Hamiltonian dynamical systems, optimal control can often be achieved by pushing the system along its naturally **unstable directions**, thereby minimizing external work. Luchinsky *et al.* (2002) demonstrated this in a chaotic oscillator: they studied the **energy-optimal escape from one attractor to another** and showed that the deterministic optimal control strategy coincides with the system’s most probable *fluctuation path* under weak noise【14†L70-L79】【14†L80-L88】. Using an analogy between the **Hamiltonian theory of rare fluctuations** (the Wentzel–Freidlin action) and Pontryagin’s optimal control Hamiltonian, they proved that the least-work way to induce a transition is to align the control force with the system’s intrinsic escape trajectory【14†L72-L80】【14†L81-L89】. In other words, the optimal perturbation “rides” the covariant unstable manifold of the chaotic attractor, exploiting the directions of positive Lyapunov exponents so that the system’s own dynamics amplify the control effect. This yields a smaller energy cost than naive or orthogonal controls【14†L80-L88】. Such results link control theory to **thermodynamic work minimization**: the chaotic system effectively behaves like a miniature thermodynamic system where an optimal protocol follows a *least dissipation path*. By targeting unstable Lyapunov modes (analogous to pushing *with* the natural flow), the control performs the minimal necessary work to achieve state change. This principle has been applied in related contexts, for example, in controlling turbulent or high-dimensional chaotic flows by actuating along leading Lyapunov vectors to trigger large-scale changes with minimal input. Overall, these studies highlight that **aligning control inputs with covariant Lyapunov vectors** or invariant manifolds can greatly reduce the “thermodynamic cost” (energy dissipation) of control in nonlinear systems.

## Score Functions, Distribution Control, and Thermodynamic Work Bounds  
Recent advances bridge optimal control, probability distributions, and thermodynamics. In stochastic thermodynamics, the optimal way to drive a system between states in finite time often involves solving a **Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation coupled to a Fokker–Planck equation**, i.e. finding a protocol that steers the entire **probability distribution** of the system【24†L29-L38】【24†L79-L88】. Sanders and Muratore-Ginanneschi (2024) developed an analytic approach for **underdamped Langevin systems**, showing that the optimal driving force can be expressed in terms of the **score function** (the gradient of the log probability density) of the state distribution【39†L139-L147】. By using the score function to transform the Fokker–Planck equation into a mass-conservation form, they leverage machine-learning parametrizations (e.g. neural networks) to solve high-dimensional control problems【39†L139-L147】. The optimal control in such cases is essentially *aligned with the score function*, meaning it pushes the system along the steepest ascent of the target distribution’s log-density – conceptually similar to following a **thermodynamic force** that minimizes free-energy-like quantities. This distribution-level control framework has yielded **tight lower bounds on work/entropy production**. In fact, formulating the state transformation as a Schrödinger bridge (an optimal transport between initial and final distributions) leads to **refinements of the second law of thermodynamics**【43†L153-L160】. Aurell *et al.* (2012) first showed that for stochastic systems one can derive a **minimum entropy production** for a given distributional transition, tighter than the traditional $\Delta F$ bound, by solving such an optimal control problem on the space of probability densities【43†L153-L160】. Subsequent works (e.g. Proesmans *et al.* 2020) have built on this to find the **minimum heat release or work dissipation** under non-standard coarse-grained constraints【43†L153-L160】. Notably, when controlling at the level of distributions (rather than just thermodynamic variables $U,V,N$), any **missing information** about microstates manifests as extra dissipation – a “cost of coarse-graining.” These modern approaches confirm that **optimal control protocols minimizing work** often involve following geodesics in probability space (or introducing auxiliary control forces proportional to score functions), and they provide quantitative limits on how much work *must* be invested given a certain coarse-grained description of the system’s state【43†L153-L160】. In summary, by uniting Lyapunov-based stability analysis with distribution-level control (score-function alignment) in a thermodynamic setting, recent research offers both general theory and practical recipes for minimal-work control of nonlinear and stochastic systems, well beyond the standard equilibrium thermodynamics framework.

“Fixing the distribution” means that, instead of prescribing just a handful of macroscopic numbers such as total energy \(U\), volume \(V\), or particle number \(N\), you prescribe the **entire probability density** of micro-states at the initial and/or final time:

\[
\rho_0(x)\quad\text{at }t=0,\qquad 
\rho_\tau(x)\quad\text{at }t=\tau,\qquad x=(q,p)\ \text{in full phase space}.
\]

In other words, the control protocol must steer the Fokker–Planck solution so that

\[
\rho(x,t=0)=\rho_0(x),\qquad
\rho(x,t=\tau)=\rho_\tau(x)
\]

**point-wise** (up to any required numerical tolerance), not just in a few moments or averages.  
If you only care about a subset of variables—say positions \(q\) but not momenta \(p\)—you can likewise “fix” the marginal density \(\rho_t(q)=\int\rho_t(q,p)\,dp\); the requirement is still an explicit functional constraint on the whole probability law, not a scalar thermodynamic variable.

So “fixing the distribution” = prescribing the **full shape** of \(\rho\) (or some chosen marginal) at the boundary times, which is a far finer specification—and therefore a different coarse-graining—than the traditional \((U,V,N)\) description.

These terms are used to model open systems with external forces, like thermostats or friction, which don't stem from a scalar potential. They're seen in situations like feedback control or systems in contact with heat baths. The associated work involves irreversible heat, useful work, and energy exchanges with reservoirs. To explain this, I’ll discuss entropy production, stochastic thermodynamics, and the decomposition of work vs. heat.

To explain non-Hamiltonian thermostats like the Gaussian isokinetic or Nosé-Hoover, I’ll emphasize that while they don’t directly perform physical work, they incorporate forces to simulate a heat bath. These forces result from coarse-graining or dissipative coupling (e.g., friction). Physically, we treat them as emerging from hidden environmental degrees of freedom. The resulting forces lead to energy changes through generalized Langevin equations, where work done by non-Hamiltonian forces follows a power rule \(P = F·v\), where \(F\) corresponds with momentum.

### 1 Why a non-Hamiltonian term is physically legitimate  

1. **Open-system coarse-graining**  
   Start with a global Hamiltonian \(H_{\text{tot}}(q,p,Q,P)=H_{\text s}(q,p)+H_{\text e}(Q,P)+H_{\text int}(q,Q)\).  
   Eliminating the environment variables \((Q,P)\) with the Mori–Zwanzig projector or by integrating out a linear bath gives the subsystem an effective equation  
   \[
     \dot q=\partial_p H_{\text s},
     \qquad
     \dot p=-\partial_q H_{\text s}-\gamma p+\eta_t\;,
   \]
   where the **friction + noise** pair \((-\gamma p,\eta_t)\) is *not* derivable from a scalar in \((q,p)\).  
   The full world is still Hamiltonian; the reduced description is non-Hamiltonian because you discarded degrees of freedom and replaced them by a dissipative force plus stochastic drive.

2. **Feedback / control hardware**  
   Real actuators (electro-magnetic coils, optical tweezers, piezo-stages) apply forces that depend on *measured* \(q,p\) and on an external control signal—not on a potential known to the system.  Such forces break symplecticity by design; the controller supplies or removes energy and entropy.

3. **Thermostats and constraints**  
   Algorithms like Gaussian isokinetic, Nosé–Hoover, or SLLOD add frictional or tensor forces that constrain kinetic energy or impose shear flow.  They intentionally violate Liouville’s theorem so that phase-space contraction equals the **heat** released to an implicit reservoir.

In short: a “non-Hamiltonian” term is the **effective** force you see after either (i) integrating out hidden variables, or (ii) closing a feedback loop with external energy supply.  Nothing fundamental is violated; the complete system (system + bath + controller) remains Hamiltonian.

---

### 2 Associated work and its thermodynamic meaning  

Let \(H_0(q,p)\) be the bare Hamiltonian and let  
\[
\dot q=\partial_p H_0+F_q(q,p,t),\qquad
\dot p=-\partial_q H_0+F_p(q,p,t),
\]
with \(F=(F_q,F_p)\) **not** derivable from a scalar.  Along a trajectory \(\Gamma_t=(q_t,p_t)\)

\[
\frac{d}{dt}H_0(q_t,p_t)=
\underbrace{\partial_q H_0\cdot F_q}_{\text{power via }F_q}
+\underbrace{\partial_p H_0\cdot F_p}_{\text{power via }F_p}.
\]

For the usual mechanical form \(H_0=p^2/2m+V(q)\):

* \(F_p=F_{\text{ext}}\) (added to the momentum equation) gives  
  \(\dot W= v\!\cdot\!F_{\text{ext}}\) — the familiar **mechanical work rate**.
* \(F_q\neq0\) (added to the velocity equation) injects power  
  \(\dot W = \nabla V(q)\!\cdot\!F_q\); this appears, for instance, in non-holonomic constraints or Nosé–Hoover chains.

**Integrated work**

\[
W[0,\tau]=\int_{0}^{\tau}\!\!dt\,
          \Bigl(\nabla_q H_0\!\cdot\!F_q
                +\nabla_p H_0\!\cdot\!F_p\Bigr).
\]

*If* \(F\) contains a dissipative part (\(\nabla\!\cdot F<0\)) the energy removed from the system is released as **heat** \(Q\) to the reservoir; the first law reads  
\[
\Delta E = W - Q,\qquad
Q = k_{\mathrm B}T\int_{0}^{\tau}\!\!dt\;(-\nabla\!\cdot F)\;\;+\;\text{(noise term)}.
\]

Thus

* **Hamiltonian perturbation (add \(\delta H\))** → all injected power is **reversible work**.  
* **Non-Hamiltonian force** → power splits into useful work and **irreversible heat**, with the latter quantified by phase-space compression and (for stochastic models) by the fluctuation–dissipation relation.

---

### 3 When to prefer each description  

| Goal | Best choice |
|------|-------------|
| Preserve symplectic structure, use canonical perturbation theory | Add \(\delta H(q,p,t)\) (Hamiltonian perturbation). |
| Model friction, thermostats, feedback cooling, minimal-work steering via control | Add \(F(q,p,t)\) directly; accept non-Hamiltonian dynamics and track work/heat with the formula above. |

Because real experiments nearly always involve uncontrolled reservoirs or active feedback, **non-Hamiltonian terms are not only allowed but indispensable**—provided you keep explicit track of the work and heat they generate via the energy-balance expression above.

In statistical mechanics, we use the Liouville measure for phase space, which leads to a formula relating thermodynamic entropy \( S \) to differential entropy \( h(\rho) \). The equation becomes \( S = k_B \left( h(\rho) - \ln h^{3N} \right) \), where the dimensionless nature of the argument is ensured by \( h^{3N} \). **Stat-mech entropy is literally a differential (Shannon) entropy with one extra, non-informational constant that fixes units.**

---

### General relation in phase space  

Let \(\Gamma=(\mathbf q_1,\mathbf p_1,\dots ,\mathbf q_N,\mathbf p_N)\) denote a microstate and  
\[
h[\rho]\;=\;-\!\int_{\Gamma} \rho(\Gamma)\,\ln\rho(\Gamma)\,d\Gamma\qquad(\text{nats})
\]
be the differential (continuous-Shannon) entropy of the phase-space density \(\rho\).

Statistical-mechanical entropy (Gibbs entropy) is  
\[
S[\rho]\;=\;-k_B\!\int_{\Gamma}\rho(\Gamma)\,
\ln\!\bigl[\Lambda\,\rho(\Gamma)\bigr]\,d\Gamma,
\tag{1}
\]
where  

* \(\displaystyle\Lambda\) is a **reference cell volume** that makes the logarithm dimensionless.  
  * Classical convention: \(\Lambda=h^{3N}\).  
  * Quantum ideal gas: \(\Lambda=(2\pi\hbar)^{3N}/N!\).

Combine (1) with the definition of \(h[\rho]\):

\[
\boxed{\;S[\rho]\;=\;k_B\bigl[h[\rho]-\ln\Lambda\bigr]\;}. \tag{2}
\]

Equation (2) is the sought identification: **thermodynamic entropy = \(k_B\) × (differential entropy minus a constant that only encodes the phase-space resolution).**

---

### Canonical ensemble ( \(T,\!V,\!N\) )  

For  
\[
\rho(\Gamma)=\frac{e^{-\beta H(\Gamma)}}{Z\,\Lambda},
\qquad
Z=\!\int_{\Gamma}\!\frac{e^{-\beta H}}{\Lambda}\,d\Gamma,
\]
insert into \(h[\rho]\):

\[
h[\rho]=
-\langle\! -\beta H -\ln Z-\ln\Lambda\rangle
=\beta\langle H\rangle+\ln Z+\ln\Lambda.
\]

Plug into (2):

\[
\boxed{\;S = k_B\bigl(\beta\langle H\rangle+\ln Z\bigr)\;},
\]

the usual canonical result that uses only standard stat-mech quantities \(Z\) and \(\langle H\rangle\).

---

### Microcanonical ensemble ( \(E,\!V,\!N\) )  

With  
\(\rho(\Gamma)=\delta[H(\Gamma)-E]/(\Omega\,\Lambda)\) and  
\(\Omega(E)=\int\delta[H(\Gamma)-E]\,d\Gamma\),

\[
h[\rho]=\ln\Omega+\ln\Lambda\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\boxed{\;S = k_B\ln\Omega(E)\;},
\]

the familiar Boltzmann entropy.

---

### Why the \(\ln\Lambda\) shift matters  

* \(h[\rho]\) depends on the **coordinate scale** of \(\Gamma\); translating momenta from kg m s\(^{-1}\) to eV s m\(^{-1}\) changes \(h\).  
* Subtracting \(\ln\Lambda\) removes that arbitrary scale, leaving a state function \(S\) that matches the thermodynamic postulates.  
* The price is that \(\Lambda\) must be specified once and for all, usually by quantum mechanics (Planck’s constant) or an explicit coarse-graining cell.

---

### Take-home formula  

\[
\boxed{\;S = k_B\,h[\rho]\;-\;k_B\ln\Lambda\;}.
\]

All standard formulas for entropy in statistical mechanics follow from this single bridge between **information-theoretic differential entropy** and **physical entropy**.

\[

| macro constraints | equilibrium density \(\rho_{\text{eq}}(\Gamma)\) |
|-------------------|--------------------------------------------------|
| \(E,V,N\) (microcanonical) | \(\displaystyle \frac{\delta[H(\Gamma)-E]}{\Omega(E)\,\Lambda}\) |
| \(T,V,N\) (canonical) | \(\displaystyle \frac{e^{-\beta H(\Gamma)}}{Z(T)V^{N}\Lambda}\) |

Once you know \(\rho_{\text{eq}}\), **statistical-mechanical entropy** is
\[

S\bigl[\rho_{\text{eq}}\bigr]
  =-k_B\!\int\!\rho_{\text{eq}}(\Gamma)\;
  \ln\!\bigl[\Lambda\,\rho_{\text{eq}}(\Gamma)\bigr]\;
  d\Gamma\;}
\tag{1}
\]
exactly the same Gibbs formula we wrote earlier.  
Because \(\rho_{\text{eq}}\) itself is a *function of the macro-parameters*, the right–hand side becomes \(S(E,V,N)\) or \(S(T,V,N)\).

*The integral over \(\Gamma\) is bookkeeping.*  It just counts all microstates compatible with the macro conditions and weights them by their probability.  Whether the macrostate is “microcanonical at \(E\)” or “canonical at \(T\),” the counting is done over individual positions and momenta—that’s unavoidable in classical stat mech.

*But the result depends only on the macrostate* because every microstate integral except the one determined by the constraints cancels out.  Two examples:

* **Microcanonical**

* **Canonical**

  S=k_B\bigl(\beta\langle H\rangle+\ln Z\bigr)=S(T,V,N).

So (1) is the **microscopic representation** of a quantity that thermo treats as a **macroscopic state function**.

Equation (1) still defines an instantaneous **Gibbs entropy** \(S[\rho_t]\), but now it *can* evolve in time and depends on the full microdistribution. ### Why “just re-labelling the macrostates” never beats the true work bound

---

#### 1 Fine-grained free energy is the real currency

For an isothermal process in contact with a bath at temperature \(T\) the exact microscopic density \(\rho(\Gamma)\) carries the **non-equilibrium free energy**

\[
F[\rho]\;=\;\langle H\rangle_\rho - T\,S_{\mathrm{fg}}[\rho]
          \;=\;k_B T\,D\!\bigl(\rho\,\Vert\,\rho_{\mathrm{eq}}\bigr)+F_{\mathrm{eq}},
\tag{1}
\]

with

\[
S_{\mathrm{fg}}[\rho]  = -k_B\!\int\rho\ln(\Lambda\rho),
\qquad
\rho_{\mathrm{eq}} = \frac{e^{-\beta H}}{Z\Lambda}.
\]

The *minimum* average work required to drive the system from \(\rho_i\) to \(\rho_f\) (with full control, arbitrarily slowly) is the free-energy drop

\[
\boxed{\, W_{\min}= \Delta F = F[\rho_f]-F[\rho_i]\, }.
\tag{2}
\]

Equation (2) is state-function-based and **independent of any coarse graining**.

---

#### 2 Coarse-grained entropies sit *inside* an information balance

Introduce a measurable macro map \(C:\Gamma\!\to\!a\) and write

\[
S_{\mathrm{cg}}\bigl(p_a\bigr)\;=\;-k_B\sum_a p_a\ln p_a,
\qquad
p_a=\int_{\Gamma:C(\Gamma)=a}\rho(\Gamma)\,d\Gamma .
\]

Decompose the fine-grained entropy through mutual information:

\[
S_{\mathrm{fg}}[\rho]
  = S_{\mathrm{cg}}(p_a)
    + \underbrace{\sum_a p_a\,S_{\mathrm{cond}}[\rho|\!a]}_{S_{\mathrm{hidden}}}
    = S_{\mathrm{cg}} + S_{\mathrm{hidden}}.
\tag{3}
\]

Both pieces can change under control operations, but their **sum**, and hence \(F[\rho]\), is what governs work.

---

#### 3 Why the naïve inequality \(W \ge k_BT\,\Delta S_{\mathrm{cg}}\) is *loose*

Data-processing tells us

\[
\Delta S_{\mathrm{cg}}
      \;=\; \Delta S_{\mathrm{fg}} - \Delta S_{\mathrm{hidden}}
      \;\le\; \Delta S_{\mathrm{fg}}
      \;=\;\beta\bigl(\Delta\langle H\rangle - \Delta F\bigr).
\tag{4}
\]

Plugging (4) into the usual Clausius inequality gives

\[
W \;\ge\; \Delta F \;\ge\; k_BT\,\Delta S_{\mathrm{cg}} .
\tag{5}
\]

Because \(\Delta S_{\mathrm{hidden}}\!\ge\!0\) whenever control does *not* keep every microcell in equilibrium, the inequality based on your chosen coarse variables is generically **strictly weaker** than the true bound (2).  Renaming macrostates merely moves entropy between “visible” and “hidden” parts; it never reduces the required \(\Delta F\).

* If your actuators couple only to \(C(\Gamma)\) and you never exploit the hidden degrees of freedom, the effective bound you observe **is indeed** \(W\ge k_BT\,\Delta S_{\mathrm{cg}}\).  
* But the *physical* minimum—achievable by someone who controls all coordinates—remains \(\Delta F\).  
* Choosing an even coarser \(C\) **lowers \(\Delta S_{\mathrm{cg}}\)** but simultaneously increases uncontrolled dissipation, leaving \(W_{\min}\) unchanged.

---

     p_a=\int_{C^{-1}(a)}\rho(\Gamma)\,d\Gamma.

*It is the σ-algebra you are obliged to keep intact.*  
Formally: the smallest collection of micro-events that your measurement, control, or logical task has to distinguish.  Examples:

* **One-bit memory** Keep only the two events “left well’’ and “right well’’; everything inside each well may be forgotten.  
* **Energy-monitoring thermostat** Keep the event “\(E\in[E_1,E_2]\)” for every chosen energy bin; forget all phase information at fixed \(E\).

* carry different mutual information \(I(\Gamma;A)\) with other micro observables,  
* couple differently to actuators or readout mechanisms,  
* impose different kinetic constraints on realising a reversible protocol.

The **microcanonical** and **canonical** ensembles are statistical constructions used to describe thermodynamic systems at equilibrium, but the names are misleading if you want clear physical intuition. Here's a direct breakdown and better naming:

---

### **Microcanonical Ensemble**
**Standard meaning**: Describes an **isolated system** with:
- Fixed total energy \( E \)
- Fixed particle number \( N \)
- Fixed volume \( V \)
- No energy exchange with the environment

**Mathematical description**:
\[
\rho(x) \propto \delta(H(x) - E)
\]
over the phase space \( x = (q,p) \). All microstates with energy exactly \( E \) are equally likely.

**Better name**:  
✅ **Fixed-energy ensemble**  
✅ **Isolated ensemble**  
❌ “Microcanonical” (the "micro" just refers to phase space microstates; “canonical” is a confusing historical artifact)

---

### **Canonical Ensemble**
**Standard meaning**: Describes a **system in thermal contact with a reservoir** at fixed temperature \( T \), with:
- Fixed \( T, N, V \)
- Energy can fluctuate (not fixed)

**Mathematical description**:
\[
\rho(x) \propto e^{-\beta H(x)}, \quad \beta = \frac{1}{k_B T}
\]

**Better name**:  
✅ **Fixed-temperature ensemble**  
✅ **Thermally open ensemble**  
✅ **Boltzmann ensemble**

---

### Why the terms suck historically:
- **“Canonical”** comes from 19th century mathematics, not physics — it just meant a standard form.
- **“Microcanonical”** was introduced later to distinguish the fully isolated case, but the prefix “micro” misleadingly sounds like it’s about microscopic systems, which it’s not.

---

### Summary table (w/ better names):

| Historical Name         | Better Name           | What’s Fixed             | What Fluctuates         | Physical Setup              |
|-------------------------|------------------------|---------------------------|--------------------------|-----------------------------|
| Microcanonical Ensemble | Fixed-Energy Ensemble  | \( E, N, V \)             | Nothing                  | Isolated system             |
| Canonical Ensemble      | Fixed-Temperature Ensemble | \( T, N, V \)             | \( E \)                  | Coupled to thermal bath     |

- **Isolated ensemble** (microcanonical)
- **Thermal ensemble** or **Boltzmann ensemble** (canonical)

Essentially, a UTM can simulate any Turing machine, including both its head movements and internal states—like the tape contents, state transitions, and memory. parts:
A universal Turing machine \(U\) must reproduce **the entire step-by-step evolution** of an arbitrary target machine \(M\), not just what \(M\)’s head does in isolation.

* **What “mimic” formally means.**  
  For every machine \(M\) and input \(w\) there is an encoding \(\langle M,w\rangle\) such that
  \[
      U(\,\langle M,w\rangle\,) \;\equiv\; M(w)
  \]
  where “\(\equiv\)” means the two tapes contain exactly the same symbol in every cell after the same number of simulated steps, the simulated head sits over the same cell, and the simulated control is in the same state.  Thus the observable behaviour—the full configuration sequence—is preserved.

* **How the simulation is arranged.**  
  \(U\) stores on its own tape  
  1. an explicit copy of \(M\)’s current tape contents,  
  2. a marker for the simulated head position, and  
  3. a record of \(M\)’s current state.  
  Its finite control is an interpreter for \(M\)’s transition table.  Each move of \(M\) is carried out by a bounded routine of \(U\) that:
    1. looks up the encoded transition \((q,s)\mapsto(q',s',d)\),  
    2. rewrites the simulated tape symbol to \(s'\),  
    3. shifts the head-marker left/right according to \(d\),  
    4. updates the stored state to \(q'\).

* **Why “head only” is insufficient.**  
  The head’s action at time \(t\) depends on **both** the symbol it reads **and** \(M\)’s current internal state.  If \(U\) tracked only the head position and ignored the evolving state register (or the symbols elsewhere on the tape), it would quickly diverge from \(M\)’s behaviour.  Correct simulation therefore requires keeping synchronized copies of **all** parts of \(M\)’s instantaneous configuration.

* **Intuitive takeaway.**  
  A universal machine does not physically replicate the hardware of \(M\); instead it **emulates** the whole machine in software.  That emulation must leave no aspect of the original configuration uncontrolled, so the “entire internals” (state register + tape contents + head position) are faithfully mirrored at every simulated step.

### Standard setup for a single-tape universal Turing machine \(U\)

| Component | Fixed by \(U\)’s own design | Supplied afresh for each simulation |
|-----------|----------------------------|-------------------------------------|
| **Transition table** of \(U\) | ✓ (hard-wired “interpreter”) | ✗ |
| **Start state** of \(U\) | ✓ (call it \(q_{\mathrm{start}}\)) | ✗ |
| **Initial head position** | ✓ (left-most non-blank cell) | ✗ |
| **Initial tape contents** | blank everywhere **except** the finite block that you prepare | ✓ |

The **only** thing you are allowed to choose at run time is that finite block on the tape.  
Everything else—the control logic, the initial state, the head start position—is immutable once \(U\) has been designed.

---

#### What must be written on the tape before the first step

A canonical layout is

\[
\boxed{\;\#\,\langle M\rangle\,\#\,w\,\#\;}
\]

* `⟨M⟩` – a self-delimiting Gödel code of the target machine \(M\) (its full transition table).
* `w` – the ordinary input string meant for \(M\).
* `#` – a special delimiter symbol reserved by \(U\).

Everything else on the tape is blank (`□`).  Once this layout is in place, \(U\) is started in \(q_{\mathrm{start}}\) with its head scanning the leftmost `#`.

---

#### What the universal machine must reproduce

1. **Configuration-by-configuration emulation (strong form).**  
   After exactly \(t\) interpreter cycles, the substring storing the *simulated* tape must equal the real tape of \(M\) after \(t\) steps; the stored head marker and stored state must match \(M\)’s true head position and control state.  This is the textbook requirement for a faithful simulation.

2. **Observable output (weak form, used in complexity theory).**  
   If \(M\) eventually halts and leaves a string \(y\) in some agreed “output zone” (say, everything left of the first blank), then \(U\) must halt with that same string \(y\) in its own output zone.  How \(U\) stores auxiliary bookkeeping symbols elsewhere on its tape is irrelevant as long as the designated output zone is identical.

---

#### Summary checklist

* **Input to \(U\) (chosen per run).**  A single finite string encoding  
  \[
     \underbrace{\,\#\,\langle M\rangle\,\#\,w\,\#\,}_{\text{initial tape block}}
  \]

* **Initial conditions that are *not* under your control.**
  * \(U\)’s interpreter transition function.
  * Start state \(q_{\mathrm{start}}\).
  * Head starting on the leftmost non-blank cell.

* **Required output.**
  * Either the *entire* configuration sequence of \(M\) (strong view), or at minimum the final output string that \(M\) would leave if it halts (weak view).  In both cases the correctness obligation applies to every possible \(M\) and input \(w\) supplied in the encoding.

This is all a universal machine needs—and all that you are allowed—to mimic an arbitrary “normal” Turing machine.

Below is a menu of the main ways in which a *metric* on a group arises from (or determines) a special kind of generating set.  In each case the algebraic number of generators is an integer, but the metric data attached to those generators—lengths, weights, or vector-field directions—controls the large-scale or fractal geometry.

---

## 1 Weighted word metrics  
Let \(G\) be any group and \(S\subset G\) a *symmetric* generating set.  
Assign a weight function \(w:S\to(0,\infty)\) and extend it additively:

\[
\|s_1\cdots s_k\|_w \;=\; \sum_{i=1}^{k} w(s_i).
\]

Then

\[
d_w(g,h)\;=\;\inf_{g=s_1\cdots s_kh}\|s_1\cdots s_k\|_w
\]

is a left-invariant metric.  The elements of *unit* weight,
\[
S_w\;=\;\{s\in S:\,w(s)=1\},
\]
are sometimes called the *metric generators* of \((G,d_w)\).  
Different choices of \(w\) (even on the same algebraic \(S\)) can produce:

* an **Ahlfors-regular** metric of integer dimension (all \(w\equiv1\));
* an **ultrametric** when the weights decay exponentially (e.g.\ \(G=\mathbb Z\), \(S=\{\pm2^n\}\) with \(w(2^{\pm n})=2^{-n}\) realises the \(2\)-adic metric; Hausdorff dimension \(0\)).

---

## 2 Sub-Riemannian (Carnot–Carathéodory) generators  
For a connected Lie group \(G\) choose a subspace \(V_1\subset\mathfrak g=\operatorname Lie G\) that *bracket-generates* \(\mathfrak g\).  
Declare a norm \(\|\cdot\|\) on \(V_1\) and let \(d_{\mathrm{cc}}\) be the length of curves whose velocity always lies in the left translates of \(V_1\).  
Here

* the “generators’’ are the vector fields in \(V_1\);
* \(\dim_{\text{top}}G\in\mathbb N\) but  
  \(\dim_H(G,d_{\mathrm{cc}})\) can be *non-integer* (e.g.\ the Heisenberg group: topological dimension \(3\), CC-Hausdorff dimension \(4\)).

---

## 3 Filtration metrics on profinite groups  
Let \(G\) be profinite with a descending chain of open normal subgroups
\[
G=G_0\supset G_1\supset G_2\supset\cdots,\qquad\bigcap_i G_i=\{e\}.
\]
Declare \(\|g\|=\min\{2^{-i}:g\in G_i\}\); this yields an ultrametric

\[
d(g,h)=\|g^{-1}h\|.
\]

The *metric generators* are the cosets \(G_i/G_{i+1}\); the Hausdorff dimension of closed subgroups varies continuously in \([0,1]\) (Barnea–Ershov–Weigel 2006).  Algebraically each \(G_i/G_{i+1}\) is still generated by a finite *integer* set.

---

## 4 Self-similar actions on rooted trees  
Groups such as the first Grigorchuk group act by automorphisms on the binary rooted tree.  Fixing the usual edge length \(2^{-n}\) on level \(n\) induces a left-invariant metric on the group via orbit maps; the Hausdorff dimension of the resulting metric space is typically irrational.  
The algebraic generating set is four elements, but the *self-similar* metric structure comes from how those generators recurse down the tree.

---

## 5 General principle  
For any *left-invariant* length function \(\ell:G\to[0,\infty)\) satisfying

\[
\ell(e)=0,\qquad\ell(g)=\ell(g^{-1}),\qquad
\ell(gh)\le\ell(g)+\ell(h),
\]

let \(S_\ell=\{g:\ell(g)=1\}\).  Then

\[
d_\ell(g,h)=\ell(g^{-1}h)=\inf_{g=s_1\cdots s_kh}\sum_{i=1}^{k}\ell(s_i),
\]

so the elements of unit length always form *a generating set determined by the metric*.  Conversely, choosing any generating set with assigned positive lengths creates such an \(\ell\).  All the fractal or large-scale geometry is encoded in those *metric generators* and their weights, while the cardinality of any generating set remains an integer.
